conclusion: Analysis of acceleration ratio during deceleration phases
Particle A decelerates from point A (at time t₀) to the time axis at 3t₀
Particle B decelerates from point B (at time 5t₀) to the time axis at 6t₀
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which is the slope of the v-t graph
Initial velocity of particle A at point A is 2v₀ (at time t₀)
Final velocity of particle A is 0 (at time 3t₀)
Time interval for deceleration of particle A is (3t₀ - t₀) = 2t₀
Initial velocity of particle B at point B is v₀ (at time 5t₀)
Final velocity of particle B is 0 (at time 6t₀)
Time interval for deceleration of particle B is (6t₀ - 5t₀) = t₀
Taking the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B: |Acceleration of A| = v₀/t₀ and |Acceleration of B| = v₀/t₀
Ratio of magnitudes of acceleration for A and B is (v₀/t₀) / (v₀/t₀) = 1
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases is 1:1 or simply 1
